Yes because you cannot be 100% sure that if your functional tests passed
with JUnit, they will pass on the device, running against the device's
kvm.  There is several KVM implementation and testing against the sun
kvm is not a proof that the device's kvm works the same (it should, but
are your sure?)

I agree


>And it's not an excuse to not run your tests on the device.

Yes, my initial point was:

-But, why use j2meUnit then? if you test only the "non midp specific" logic
-you can also relay on JUnit.
-I found it very easy to modify the test suit to run as midlet on an
-emulator, now you can use the textui to assert RMS operations etc.

-I recommend to invoke testsuites from midlets added to your suite, on
deploy
-you can easly remove them.

>I don't see the big picture.  Let's imagine you develop an application
>for the PalmOS.  Since you cannot run JUnit on the PalmOS I don't see
>how using a MIDlet Wrapper for j2meUnit will help you run your JUnit
>Suite on the device.

>Can you clarify your point?  Thanks
the point is:
I am the guy that WANTS to run j2meUnit on devices!
But i agree with your argument now, that it would be better to test on a
kvm, even when you only test against business logic.
And running xUnit you want to test only business logic! <- is this statement
right?
The thing that confused me is that business logic at an superficial view has
nothing to do with using a kvm or not kvm.


thanks
roland
